titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Thomas Wentworth Higginson Letters, 1854-1906
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, November 2021

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: Letters by Higginson, mainly relating to literary and personal matters and to lectures delivered by him. Includes "The Nonsense of It. Short Answers to Common Objections against Woman Suffrage." Addressees include William Bliss Carman, Daniel Coit Gilman, Julia Ward Howe, Charles Henry Miller, John Codman Ropes, and Laird Simons. In an 1854 letter to an unidentified recipient, Higginson wrote regarding "free church" organizations that might offer suitable positions, sent a "cheap" tract on women's rights, and requested a "unprejudiced account" of New York Central College in McGrawville, New York. In a 1897 letter, he wrote to a book club organizer regarding a reprinting.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: Thomas Wentworth Higginson letters, 1854-1906, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, November 2021.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Thomas Wentworth Higginson was a minister, Army officer, author, and social reformer, of Cambridge, Massachusetts.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Letters by Higginson, mainly relating to literary and personal matters and to lectures delivered by him. Includes "The Nonsense of It. Short Answers to Common Objections against Woman Suffrage." Addressees include William Bliss Carman, Daniel Coit Gilman, Julia Ward Howe, Charles Henry Miller, John Codman Ropes, and Laird Simons. In an 1854 letter to an unidentified recipient, Higginson wrote regarding "free church" organizations that might offer suitable positions, sent a "cheap" tract on women's rights, and requested a "unprejudiced account" of New York Central College in McGrawville, New York. In a 1897 letter, he wrote to a book club organizer regarding a reprinting.
